abstract: The ban, requested by Apple in a patent dispute, applies to older smartphones and tablets and will have little effect on current Samsung products.

abstract: The Brixmor Property Group sold more shares than it had expected in its initial public offering, reflecting strong demand from investors for commercial real estate.

abstract: Federal gridlock over the debt ceiling could adversely affect the bottom lines of big Wall Street banks and firms, a report by Thomas P. DiNapoli, the New York State comptroller, asserts.

abstract: The increase of 139,000 subscribers was certainly helped by CBS’s dispute with Time Warner Cable. In Latin America, growth slowed significantly.

abstract: SAC’s chief financial officer said that portfolio managers were rewarded special “Cohen tag bonuses” for ideas that translated into windfall gains.

headline: Investors Cheer Deal to End Shutdown but Worry About Reruns
abstract: Many investors were left worrying that the budget crises that have become more frequent in recent years could spin on endlessly.

headline: Complacency on Wall Street Could Be Worse Than a Panic
abstract: Market participants don’t think that the government will default on its debts, but the ideological fissures in Washington are deeper than investors grasp.

headline: Skip Hop, Maker of Children’s Gear, Sells Majority Stake to Equity Firm
abstract: The investment is the latest by Fireman Capital, a five-year-old firm that has scored several big hits in recent years.

headline: Kimberly-Clark to Spin Off Health Care Unit
abstract: The business that would be separated focuses on selling surgical and anti-infection products and medical devices for pain management, respiratory and digestive health.

headline: Taiwan May Miss Out on Jia Zhangke’s ‘A Touch of Sin’
abstract: A controversial new work by China’s most famous art house director, Jia Zhangke, may not be shown in Taiwan after failing to get released in mainland China.

headline: Redefining the Next Policy Debate
abstract: An undue emphasis on the federal deficit and debt is driving the next phase of Congressional discussions, and more attention needs to be paid to jobs, infrastructure, income and other issues, an economist writes.

headline: UBS to Buy Back Bonds to Reduce Balance Sheet and Expenses
abstract: The Swiss bank said it expected to incur a small loss on the buyback, but believed that would be offset by a decrease in its future interest expense.

abstract: A Purple Heart recipient becomes an entrepreneur. How to use Instagram to increase sales. Will the holidays be happy?

headline: Boies Schiller Again Pays Associates Generous Bonuses
abstract: The law firm is poised to pay bonuses of as much as $300,000 to some associates, with the average young lawyer taking home an additional $85,000.

headline: Today in Small Business: What the Owner Takes Home
abstract: Owner salaries have declined from a year ago — and nearly 15 percent of small-business owners work a second job to make ends meet.

abstract: If the federal budget impasse lasts a week or less, analysts say the forgone expenditures will be too slight to extend the day of reckoning for the debt ceiling.

abstract: In making public its prospectus, Twitter sets the clock on one of the most anticipated stock sales of the year and shows how important mobile is to its business.

abstract: The less-than-creative tax structure of the $3.5 billion deal for US Foods could cost the combined company $200 million.

abstract: Del Monte Foods said that it planned to rename itself to reflect its focus on pet food brands like Meow Mix and Kibbles ‘n Bits.

headline: Daily Report: Virtual Currencies Seek to Challenge Bitcoin
abstract: Several species of electronic money are striving to emerge from the shadow of bitcoin and gain widespread acceptance by offering varying degrees of anonymity and ease of use.

abstract: Empire State Realty Trust, owner of the Empire State Building, has completed its initial public offering after months of legal wrangling, raising about $930 million.

abstract: Business development companies are publicly traded and return big dividends, making them attractive to small investors. But they also come with high risk.

abstract: Many economists and policy makers seem reluctant to acknowledge the impact of higher marginal tax rates on the labor market, an economist writes.

headline: So Far, So Good for Twitter
abstract: Twitter reached a valuation of $31.7 billion as it began trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, a figure the company will have to justify by showing a profit sooner rather than later.

abstract: The hedge fund disclosed on Thursday that it owns a 5 percent stake in the business software maker as it urged the company to consider a sale or other changes.

abstract: The departure of Sol Kumin underscores the transformation of SAC Capital Advisors to a symbol for corporate crime.

headline: Taking on the Task of 5: A Party Veteran on Xi Jinping
abstract: Bao Tong, an official who was purged in 1989, is an astute observer of Chinese politics and offers his take on the Communist Party’s plans to revitalize the economy and strengthen its authority.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Computer Club of Jobs and Wozniak Reunites, and What’s Next for @Jack?
abstract: Monday’s highlights from around the Web include a reunion of the computer club where Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak first showed off their wares. Plus, a profile of Jack Dorsey, a Twitter co-founder.

abstract: To promote its standing in China, JPMorgan Chase turned to a consulting firm run by the only daughter of Wen Jiabao. | JPMorgan Chase got a very negative taste of Twitter’s power. | Snapchat has joined the list of tech companies with no money coming in but multiple sky-high takeover offers. | Multinational corporations are avoiding taxes by moving intellectual property overseas.

abstract: Shopify’s financing was led by the venture capital arm of the Canadian pension fund OMERS and the investment firm Insight Venture Partners.

abstract: After Yang Zhong, 16, was taken away by police on suspicion of “spreading online rumors,” he says they tortured him. Now he’s suing for 7 renminbi, one for each day of detention, and an apology.

abstract: Some activist hedge funds are angling for certain of their board nominees to be paid twice. | The frenzy over bitcoin feels a bit like a 1999-style craze. | A deal that would have been the biggest law firm merger of the year was called off because of client conflicts.

abstract: How to keep employees happy. Super Bowl ads are already sold out. Do you micro-schedule your day?

abstract: Zhang Yimou is reportedly under investigation following allegations that he fathered seven children, a violation of China’s family planning rules.

headline: Life in A Refugee Camp Near Muzaffarnagar
abstract: A month after the riots broke out, about 24,000 people continue to live in refugee camps in the districts of Shamli and Muzaffarnagar, according to the state administration officials.

abstract: The development of Bitcoin, the virtual currency that is not issued by any government, presents challenges for the authorities to use laws that were not designed for the digital world to combat illegal conduct, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.

abstract: PRS Legislative Research, an independent research house in New Delhi, found the 15th Lok Sabha falls short compared to its predecessors.

abstract: On the importance of role models, in real life and on TV.

headline: In Europe, Thousands of Requests for Facebook Data
abstract: Richard Allan, the director for public policy for Facebook in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, said the company received 8,500 requests from the European Union affecting 10,000 user accounts during the first six months of this year.

abstract: After trying to ignore shareholder activism, companies are realizing that preparation and engagement can bring better results.

abstract: Aside from admitting some wrongdoing, the bank is expected to pay about $100 million to resolve the case with Commodity Futures Trading Commission as soon as this week.

abstract: The Federal Housing Finance Agency,which helped forge a tentative $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase split off with its own deal on Friday, extracting a $4 billion payout from the nation’s biggest bank.

abstract: After months of wrangling, the bank agreed to a statement of facts with the government that provides new details into how it assembled mortgage securities sold from 2005 through 2008.

abstract: Countless prosecutors, regulators and congressional aides swap their government résumés for seven-figure salaries at law firms and lobbying shops.

abstract: Illicit activity is rising in the virtual currency market, where there is an increasing amount of real money but few rules and even less oversight.

abstract: The payment represents the Swiss National Bank’s share of the remaining equity value of a portfolio of trouble assets set up five years ago to rescue UBS.

abstract: Twitter has been losing money, allowing it to legally avoid paying corporate income taxes. But it may have to start paying taxes sooner rather than later, the author writes.

abstract: Leander Kahney, the author of several books about Apple, took on the challenge of analyzing Apple through the lens of the design process used by Jonathan Ive, the company’s head of design.

abstract: Competing with Amazon. Overcoming toxic employee behaviors. How to teach your children to be entrepreneurs.

abstract: The defense’s case will take considerably less time. It said it might call one witness on Monday, and then both sides will present their closing arguments.

abstract: Owners of start-ups often decide to pursue growth rather than profits. But without profits and positive cash flow, the businesses can have a hard time surviving.

abstract: The New Express, a scrappy tabloid in Guangzhou, said its reporter had been detained while investigating the finances of China’s second-largest construction equipment maker.

abstract: An investment manager offers some signs that your country might be in distress.

abstract: Antitrust regulators say they will require the sale of a television station in St. Louis owned by the Belo Corporation for the $1.5 billion acquisition to proceed.

abstract: Big banks may be hiding losses on delinquent loans because forcing them into foreclosure could prompt the Federal Housing Administration to refuse to cover them, according to a report in The American Banker.

abstract: Some conservatives propose to abolish both employer-based health coverage and Medicaid, relying on a private market with subsidies, a plan that seems politically and structurally unrealistic, an economist writes.

abstract: Editors at Bloomberg News use a code to keep articles on Chinese politics and social issues away from the eyes of powerful people in China who might be offended, Bloomberg employees say.

abstract: On “60 Minutes” Sunday night, Jeff Bezos of Amazon showed a video of a tiny helicopter seizing a package from a warehouse and airlifting it to a house.

abstract: The search giant is making less money on advertising as usage patterns change, but its latest financial report sent its stock up in after-hours trading.

abstract: Over five days, India will hold its breath as it bids farewell to Sachin Tendulkar, its greatest, and most beloved, sporting hero.

abstract: The offer by Bayer of Germany is 27 percent above Algeta’s closing share price on Monday. The companies are partners in a new prostate cancer drug.

abstract: With Medicaid’s expansion under the Affordable Care Act, an Oregon study finds little impact on the labor market from Medicaid coverage.

abstract: The security company says it will not pursue the “highly opportunistic” offer from the British private equity firm Charterhouse Capital Partners.

headline: China’s Dynasties, in Song
abstract: The order of China’s dynasties can be a complicated puzzle for students of Chinese history. The Harvard professors William Kirby and Peter Bol suggest singing them to the tune of “Frère Jacques.”

headline: A Landmark Turn in India’s Medical Negligence Law
abstract: The Supreme Court’s 60.8 million rupee award took into consideration the complex socioeconomic conditions of Dr. Kunal Saha, the pain his wife endured, the doctor’s loss of income and his copious legal expenses.

headline: Salesforce Picks Second Winner for Criticized Hackathon
abstract: Salesforce.com said its $1 million prize for a recent contest for outside developers was a record, but following an outcry about how the contest was run, it has decided to give the top two companies $1 million each. Salesforce didn’t really acknowledge fault, but says it could have done a better job.

headline: Bank Records Sought in Offshore Tax Inquiry
abstract: A federal judge gave the government permission to seek data from five Wall Street banks on American clients suspected of hiding assets at an unrelated Caribbean bank.

abstract: Remotely controlled aircraft have provided valuable images of events that are difficult to reach, including the recent typhoon in the Philippines.

abstract: A retired police lieutenant from New Jersey founded a company that conducts burials at sea.

headline: Syria Seen as Most Dire Refugee Crisis in a Generation
abstract: The Syrian war has created a refugee crisis bigger than the one unleashed by the Rwandan genocide, and humanitarian groups and governments say they expect it to go on for years.

abstract: A WQXR campaign aims to present the composer in an accessible, even quirky, light, while reminding New Yorkers that the radio station offers great programming.

headline: Tesla Posts Smaller Loss, but Shares Start to Temper
abstract: Tesla, the maker of an electric automobile, trimmed its loss to $38 million on revenue of $431 million, compared with a loss of $111 million on revenue of $50 million a year ago.

abstract: The militant Haqqani network’s war against the Soviets more than two decades ago is still spoken of in reverential tones in the mountains of eastern Afghanistan, but support has turned to resentment in some corners.

abstract: Samsung Electronics said it would double its dividend and increase spending on acquisitions, but some investors grumbled that the company was still being stingy with its cash.

abstract: Frederick Hutson served time for marijuana distribution. His company, Pigeonly, offers prison inmates and efficient way to receive photos from loved ones.

abstract: How to deal with a colleague who brings much of his home life to the office? A hospital doctor asks the Workologist for help.

abstract: The Palestinian negotiators on Thursday offered to resign in protest over the continuing construction of Israeli settlements, but the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, was not likely to accept them.

abstract: In Warsaw, United Nations delegates suggested that a warming planet had turned Typhoon Haiyan, considered one of the strongest storms to make landfall on record, into a lethal monster.

abstract: Even innocuous topics have become controversial for Wikipedia editors from China, Taiwan and Hong Kong, and compounding the issue are language differences.

abstract: Though three-quarters of its users are outside the United States, only a modest portion of its ad revenue is generated there. But it’s growing fast.

abstract: The priest, who was seized in Cameroon, appears to have been taken by militants who are lashing out at France for financial and ideological reasons.

abstract: The series, which has more than 500 episodes, has been widely syndicated but not on cable TV. The price was expected to approach $1 billion.

abstract: The longer a person of retirement age puts off collecting Social Security, the more money he or she will collect annually — much like buying an annuity.

abstract: Christian Wulff resigned in 2012 after prosecutors began investigating allegations that he accepted bribes and favors from businessmen.

abstract: One way that doctors stand out from the general population is in advance planning for the end of life, something that is gradually finding acceptance.

abstract: The attackers behind the siege of the Westgate shopping mall had been living in Nairobi and plotted the attack for several months, a Western official briefed on the investigation said.

abstract: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, raised the possibility that thousands of international peacekeeping troops in Africa might have to be temporarily redeployed in the Central African Republic, one of the most unstable on the continent.

abstract: The executive, María de los Angeles González, 55, agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, suggesting there could be further revelations about corruption at the government-controlled bank, the Economic and Social Development Bank of Venezuela.

headline: Planning for a Future in the Face of Terminal Illness
abstract: People who have terminal diseases are living longer. Experts say simple strategies can make the most of the money at hand for those with foresight.

abstract: The plan, submitted to a judge for approval, would pay an estimated 8,000 patients who have been forced to have the flawed all-metal artificial hip replaced.

abstract: A wave of attacks against Shiite Muslims killed at least 47 people and wounded dozens as they were marking the holy day of Ashura.

headline: Siding With Google, Judge Says Book Search Does Not Infringe Copyright
abstract: The Authors Guild said it disagreed with the decision and planned to appeal. Google said it was “delighted” with the outcome.

headline: More Cities Consider Using Eminent Domain to Halt Foreclosures
abstract: Several cities are weighing the purchase of mortgages from underwater homes — by force if necessary — to curb foreclosures and falling property values.
